column4: hey people, how to run a command with low priority possible? I tried nice + perl /home/user/script.pl... but it say "nice: +1: No such file or directory"
nice -n 5 perl ... (or whatever priority change you want instead of 5)
leaving off the -n switch defaults to "10"
hmm I tried -n19 << this is mos low possible? ps: I'm not the router
yes, that's the lowest favourable scheduling
hmm work fine now, but if I request it from a script the proccess still using 90%+ of cpu
niceness is not the same as processor usage. if a low priority task is the only one available to run, it will consume a large fraction of the cpu time (since it's not competing with anything else).
exec script.sh and content is comenthing like it: " nice -n 19 perl $script_DIR/script.pl "
no limit of cpu usage is configured by user I think
well, what's the problem, exactly? it seems to be doing what you told it to do.
i'm clearly not getting what you're trying to do, and what results you expect. is there a reason you're running the script via nice if you're the only one on the system?
ok lets me try explain better my situation..
also, how are you invoking the command in the script?

I have one small shell accont to run my eggdrop. My bot run a tcl that execute this command one time per day: " exec /home/user/script.sh " and the contect of this script is somenthing like it: " nice -n 19 perl $PISG_DIR/pisg.pl ". Right, if I just run the command nice directly in terminal, all run fine with no cpu abuse, but from script still getting 90% or more cpu usage.
try running nice at a higher level (nice exec foo.sh...) i imagine nice is setting a value which is lost once the shell spawned by your script vanishes.
work fine now, the correct way is: exec nice -n 19 command, my fault tried nice first. Thank you!
